header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.11 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
    • recompile with fassociative-math (included in Ofast or ffast-math) to extend loop vectorization to FP reductions.
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by:
  • reading data from caches/RAM (load units are a bottleneck)
  • writing data to caches/RAM (the store unit is a bottleneck)
By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 7.00 to 5.50 cycles (1.27x speedup).

hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
  • QuadTree::calculateForce(Particle*, double&, double&) const: 1 occurrences<>

  • writing data to caches/RAM (the store unit is a bottleneck)
By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 12.50 to 10.33 cycles (1.21x speedup).

hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
  • QuadTree::calculateForce(Particle*, double&, double&) const: 1 occurrences<>

header:
Warnings:
Detected a function call instruction: ignoring called function instructions.
Rerun with --follow-calls=append to include them to analysis  or with --follow-calls=inline to simulate inlining.
0% of peak computational performance is used (0.16 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
  • Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 12.50 to 4.00 cycles (3.12x speedup).

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
    • recompile with fassociative-math (included in Ofast or ffast-math) to extend loop vectorization to FP reductions.
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
Only 22% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 12.50 to 1.87 cycles (6.67x speedup).

gain.workaround:
• Read less array elements
  • Write less array elements
  • Provide more information to your compiler:
    • hardcode the bounds of the corresponding 'for' loop
gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by:
  • reading data from caches/RAM (load units are a bottleneck)
  • writing data to caches/RAM (the store unit is a bottleneck)
By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 12.50 to 10.00 cycles (1.25x speedup).

header:
The loop is defined in:
  • /usr/include/c++/14.2.1/bits/stl_vector.h:1131
  • /usr/include/c++/14.2.1/bits/stl_iterator.h:1068

Warnings: Non-innermost loop: analyzing only self part (ignoring child loops). This loop has 3 execution paths. The presence of multiple execution paths is typically the main/first bottleneck. Try to simplify control inside loop: ideally, try to remove all conditional expressions, for example by (if applicable):
  • hoisting them (moving them outside the loop)
  • turning them into conditional moves, MIN or MAX
Ex: if (x<0) x=0 => x = (x<0 ? 0 : x) (or MAX(0,x) after defining the corresponding macro)
